name: Mail It In
description:
Deck that goes all in on trying to blackmail your way into remotes. I'm experimenting with blackmail, any other ideas/comments are welcome. This build starts out aggressive, pushing at centrals, hopefully you can score an agenda and not need the notoriety. Once you land a bad pub, you sit back and wait. I will probably try it with the other bad pub options as well, activist support and tallie. Hopefully there will be more to come from ffg. A similar build in criminal might work well, could use running interference for a similar effect to blackmail.

Played a few games with it and it's about as awkward as you would expect, replacing notoriety, frame job black mail with vamp, medium and imp would be a better deck. Once they have bad pub it can be pretty annoying, but even then it means you can never run their remote without blackmailing it, so it's easy to bait you into running at a trap or upgrade. Also unlike vamp, blackmail doesn't hurt the corps Econ, so if you miss or score they are still in a good position. Also fast advance makes you lose. The source slows them down for a turn, but I found even an extra turn isn't enough to get the whole bad pub thing setup. You need to draw your knights and blackmails early, Econ, a frame job, and score an agenda or notoriety, then you are in a good position.

name: Omega Kit
description:
A deck I've been tailoring since Fear and Loathing dropped.

The concept is to set up a gimmick rig that can almost guarantee a break through on a single server ONCE per turn. Cyber-Cypher is great value coupled with Rielle's ability to break the outermost ICE, and Omega makes an appearance once a second ICE drops to break the innermost. From here, the middle ICE can be taken care of with Knights or Parasite.

Magnum Opus is a necessity over Professional Contacts in this deck. It can be modded in for value, and provides a stable economy to make sure your rig can be SMC'd exactly when needed. A worthy note, Stimhack can pull out an Omega for free with a SMC installed, at the cost of one brain damage. Be cautious using this tactic when playing against Jinteki!

Since Rielle relies on making one good run per turn, 3x R&D Interfaces make her runs super worth. Deep Red is the best console for this deck, since it allows the Knights to be hosted mid-run off of a SMC, and frees up valuable MUs.

Inti is a recent addition that I am testing. It is purely situational, to be used only when Wraparound is rezzed. Otherwise don't bother. Deus Ex and Sharpshooter are situational as well; SMC or Clone Chip for them when needed.

name: HB Ice and Tell
description:
Original list.

So I don't like most other's list for big ice. The idea of this deck is to get Sansan City Grid behind a Wotan and sweep, rezzing Wotan with Bioroid Efficiency. Its is 12 to crack with Corroder, so even if they do break it they get set pretty far back. If you can rez Wotan for 14, do so unless you are playing Criminal.

Wotan and Janus and Heimdall get cheated into play. Janus always gets Oversight AI. Janus can get broken by Fairy and Dues Ex, and with no end the run it usually sits over R&D to look intimidating. Never straight rez it, unless they only have 1 click or less. You're not looking to kill, so the brain damage is only some incremental value.

Heimdall 2.0 is in the realm of being able to realistically rezzed normally. You can't stick it in a remote by itself to protect an agenda, because trading 1 Brain for an Agenda is always worth. It can protect you're assets and centrals just fine.

Viktor, Eli, and Ichi are ice that do a lot of your work. They protect your big ice from getting clicked through, and they cost a whole lot for the popular breakers.

Ice wall/paper wall, and Rototurret are cheap end the runs, and also help against Atman.

Otherwise you're assets generate a lot of money. If they don't trash your campaigns your going to be rolling in dough. Enough so that you can usually fight through siphons. Try to protect them. Putting them behind 1 ice usually discourages trashing.

I've been playing with the number of ice in each, but don't go above 2 in Heimdall, Janus and Wotan. Thinking of dropping 1 Oversight AI for extra influence in an Ice Wall or something.

name: HB Blood on the ICE
description: This deck is all about making the runner make hard expensive choices. Forcing them to spend 18 credits to run an Iceberg just to hit a Cerebral Overwriter or Edge of the World. Score a Wootan early and let the runner forget they may meed 3 extra credits to break to score that agenda.
